column2: Can 700-level courses count for graduate credit?

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
column3: Students, for compelling nonacademic reasons, submits an approved petition to drop a course during the withdrawal period. Failure to officially withdraw will result in an AF grade, which is maintained on the official student record and included in the grade point average (GPA). Not attending classes does not constitute an automatic withdrawal.

column2: Can I transfer credits into my program?
column3: Graduate-level courses taken prior to admission may be transferred into the program and applied to the total only if they were not taken while matriculated in another degree program, as per Graduate School policy. Transfer credits must be formally approved and appear on the UNH transcript in order for them to count towards the degree requirements.

column2: How do I apply to grad school?
column3: The final oral examination is conducted by the doctoral committee and is intended to give the candidate an opportunity to defend the dissertation. While it is desirable for all committee members to participate in dissertation defenses, whether in person or through virtual means such as conference calls or video conferencing, outside scholars are not required to be present at the defense. Departments will determine how to obtain meaningful and substantive evaluations from external members in consultation with the Graduate School.

column2: How many credits are required in the Core Curriculum for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): Core Curriculum The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.

column2: What is the credit range for the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and an Graduate biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits) and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able complete the degree in 18 months.

column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

column2: What is the overall purpose of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): Core Curriculum The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.

column2: What transferable professional skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what will students learn to develop and operate?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: What is the minimum grade for earning graduate credit?
column3: The University of New Hampshire requires a minimum of three hours of student academic work each week. For each credit hour, the University requires, at least six but no more than 10 thesis credits. The work must be completed and submitted to the instructor by the date agreed upon with the instructors, but not later than the last day of classes of the semester immediately following the one in which the incomplete was granted (800-­ and 900-level courses only; mid-semester deadline for 400–­, 500–, 600-, and 700—­level classes). If extraordinary circumstances arise, if extraordinary circumstance arises

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: Applicants for the degree must meet admission requirements, develop and complete an approved program of study in consultation with their guidance committee, complete required coursework, undergo an annual assessment review by the Doctoral Advisory Committee, draft a dissertation proposal to advance to candidacy, write and present the dissertation, and pass the final oral examination.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?

column2: What are the Ph.D. time limits at UNH?
column3: The University of New Hampshire is in compliance with the federal definition of credit hour. For each credit hours, the University requires at a minimum the equivalent of three hours of student academic work each week assuming an 15-week semester (student workload for shorter length terms must be increased proportionally per week to maintain required approximately 45 hours per credit per term). Academic work includes, but is not limited to, direct faculty instruction, e-learning, research, studio work, fieldwork, performance, internships, and practica.

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: A student who receives more than one grade below B- will be required to withdraw from the certificate program. Only courses completed with a grade of B or higher may be used to fulfill certificate requirements. Graduate students must obtain written permission of their adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the endorsement of the Graduate School dean before the adjustment is made. The final oral examination is conducted by the major department and is intended to give the candidate an opportunity to defend the dissertation. While it is desirable for all committee members to participate in dissertation defenses, whether in person or through virtual means such as conference calls or video conferencing, outside scholars are

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: Academic integrity is a core value at the University of New Hampshire. The members of its academic community both require and expect one another to conduct themselves with integrity.

column2: Can I transfer credits into my program?
column3: Graduate-level courses taken prior to admission may be transferred into the program and applied to the total only if they were not taken while matriculated in another degree program, as per Graduate School policy. Transfer credits must be formally approved and appear on the UNH transcript in order for them to count towards the degree requirements.

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: A minimum of 30 credits must be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission). Students failing to make adequate advancement toward completion of the program are subject to dismissal in advance. Extensions to the four-year time limit will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: A student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of required thesis credit that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs.

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Applicants who cannot enroll in the term for which admission was offered may request to have their admission deferred for up to one year. Such requests must be in writing and will be considered only once. Because enrollments are limited and competition for admission may vary from year to year, such requests may not be granted.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: University policy requires full-time degree students that are enrolled in at least one in-person course to have health insurance as a condition of enrollment. Some students have the option of waiving this requirement if they present proof of adequate coverage; alternatively, students can acquire an affordable health benefits plan sponsored by the University: the UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP).

column2: How many elective credits are required in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): The MS Biotech:IBMS program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and the Graduate BioTech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits) and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able complete the degree in as little as 12 months. column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: A student successfully completing the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to:: Successfully undertake a substantial Capstone experience (in industry or in an academic laboratory) in which the student demonstrates sufficient knowledge of the professional, experimental, ethical, communication, and laboratory standards relevant to the selected placement.

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): Curriculum The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.

column2: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?
column3: A student successfully completing the Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to:: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area. column2: How many total program credits are composed of core, elective, and capstone work in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (MS Biotech:IBMS) program at the University of New Hampshire is a STEM-designated graduate degree program that offers its students innovative experiential learning opportunities and delivers an content-rich, skills-based, and highly versatile curriculum for individuals seeking to advance their careers in the biotechnology, pharmaceutical and biomanufacturing sectors.

column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and an Graduate biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits) and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of required thesis credits within each program can vary.

column2: What is the overall purpose of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (MS Biotech:IBMS) program at the University of New Hampshire offers its students innovative experiential learning opportunities and delivers a content-rich, skills-based, and highly versatile curriculum for individuals seeking to advance their careers in the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, or biomanufacturing sectors.

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

column2: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): The MS Biotech:IBMS program is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transitional skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills.

column2: How is the scientific method applied in the biotechnology: industrial and biomedical sciences (m.s.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (MS Biotech:IBMS) program at the University of New Hampshire is a STEM-designated graduate degree program that offers its students innovative experiential learning opportunities, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.

column2: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (MS Biotech:IBMS) program at the University of New Hampshire is a STEM-designated graduate degree program that offers its students innovative experiential learning opportunities and delivers  content-rich, skills-based, and highly versatile curriculum for individuals seeking to advance their careers in the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, or biomanufacturing sectors.

column2: What specialty development is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The biotechnology industry in New England is currently expanding at a substantial rate (2018 Job Trends Forecast, MassBioEd Foundation) and graduates of the M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be well-prepared for anticipated growth in jobs projected for the biotech, pharmaceutical, and biomanufacturing sectors.

column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, three hours of academic work each week assuming a 15-week semester (student workload for shorter length terms must be increased proportionally per week to maintain required approximately 45 hours per credit per term). Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Academic work reflects intended learning outcomes and is verified through evidence of student achievement. Thesis Credit: The University of New Hampshire is in compliance with the federal definition

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program provide applied experience?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what kinds of threats will graduates address?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): With a greater emphasis on the collection and storage of big data, information security and cloud computing, the demand for cybersecurity engineers has never been higher. column2: Which type of systems does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program focus on securing?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences. Program Learning Outcomes: Apply security principles and practices to maintain operations in the presence of risks and threats.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what three actions will students learn regarding secure information systems?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences. Students are encouraged to review these materials, consult with program advisors, or seek clarification from faculty to ensure they understand and meet these expectations.
